FOOD PRODUCTION SCHEMES, IRELAND.
Memorandum prepared in compliance with Chief Secretary's Minute of 17th March, 1917.
Week ended 18th December, 1918.
The following in a brief statement on the work of the Department during the past week in furtherance of increased Food eduction in Ireland:-
LOANS FOR AGRICULTURAL IMPLEMENTS.
Twenty one applications for loans for agricultural implements are received by the Department during the past week. The total ? of machinery ordered from the beginning of the present year to ? under the Scheme, amounts to Â£104,694.
COMPULSORY TILLAGE.
In connection with the inspection of holdings on occupiers failed to ? with the requirements of the Tillage Orders in ?, arrangements have now been made for the allocation of 46 inspectors to 46 different districts throughout the country. The ? of those Inspectors will, it is anticipated, start work early the new year.
A deputation representing the Dublin Dairymen and Cowkeepers ? recently received by the Department. The members of the deputation ? that owners of lands which had been let to Dairymen during the ? 1918 were under the impression that these lands, having been ? from the requirements of the Tillage Orders in 1918, (by ? of their having been required for the grazing of milch cows) would continue to be exempted in 1919 whether the lands were used ? the grazing of milch cows or of dry stock, and that owing to this ? competition was being met from dry stock feeders at auctions these lands with the result that rents were being forced up to an ? limit. The Department assured the deputation that lands ? wore exempted in 1918 for the grazing ? of milch cows would not exempted in 1919 if used for grazing dry stock. As the matter is considerable importance from the point of view of the milk supply of City of Dublin, the Department issued a press notice on the subject the information of the public.
PROGRESS OF FARM WORK.
The weather was fairly good during the past week, but heavy ? at night rendered work impossible on damp retentive soils. ? progress was made with ? ploughing in ? the drier ?. Catch crops and early sown winter wheat are very forward are still growing vigorously.
The lifting of potatoes is now practically completed. In districts the mild weather has caused considerable sprouting of

potatoes in pits. About three-fourths of the turnip crop has been pulled and stored. The yield generally ? below average. inter pastures have still a good bottom of grass, and outlying cattle are in excellent condition. Fodder is being used sparingly.
FLAX.
Scutching Results. The yields of scutched flax in the flax mills are now considerably higher than those obtained earlier in the season, but are still under average.
Labour Disputes. The scutchers in counties Mayo and Wicklow, who were on strike, have resumed work. There have been no further developments in connection with the threat of members of the Ulster Flax Scutchers' Union to go out on strike.
Flaxseed Tests. During the past two seasons the Department have conducted fairly exhaustive field trials with a view to ascertaining the suitability for Irish requirements of the different varieties of flaxseed. Better results have been obtained from Yorkshire. Dutch and Russian ? than from Canadian and Japanese. As between canadian and Japanese, the former of these two seeds has proved the more satisfactory. The opinions of ? numerous flax mill owners which have been ascertained, confirm the results of the Department's field trials.
Disposal of Tow. Further reports received during the week indicate that some millowners are still contravening the Scutch Mills (Ireland/Order, 1918, with regard to the disposal of tow, and that there a general disposition on the part on the part of millowners to purchase unscutched tow at prices much under its value. The Department are endeavouring through their flax Inspectors and Instructors, and by issuing market reports, to provide flax-growers with information regarding the values of tows.
Flax Scutching Order, 1918. Owing to the difficulties arising out of the unwillingness of certain insurance companies to undertake the insurance of scutchmills, the form of this order has not yet been finally decided upon. Arrangements have been made to settle the question of insurance with the companies, if possible.
Export of Irish Saved Flaxseed to Holland. A proposal has been made to export home-saved seed to Holland and the Department are in communication with the War Office in the matter.
MAINTENANCE OF LIVE STOCK.
During the period from 10th to 16th instant, inclusive, 249 applications for licences to slaughter or export heifers, 83 applications for licences to slaughter bulls or bullocks, 151 applications for licences to export milch cows were received, and 30 applications for licences to export store Heifers and stripper cows were received.
